Expectation1: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation1: An easygoing regular politely asks for a tiny adjustment to their fringe.
Expectation2: Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the volunteer coordinator
Situation2: New safety steps were highlighted during the last briefing and everyone was asked to apply them consistently.
Story:
I was finishing up a trim for Mrs. Lee, one of my favorite regulars, when she glanced in the mirror and smiled. “Could you just take a little more off the fringe?” she asked, her tone gentle. I nodded, reaching for my scissors, but my mind flashed back to the volunteer briefing from last night. The coordinator had been clear: “No sharp tools left unattended, even for a second. Safety first, always.” I’d promised to follow every new step, and I knew I was expected to set an example for the other volunteers at the shelter later today.

But here, in the salon, my client expected me to focus on her needs, to listen and make sure she left happy. I could see she trusted me, and I didn’t want to let her down. Yet, the thought of the new safety rules tugged at me. Should I pause and double-check every step, even if it meant slowing down and possibly making Mrs. Lee feel uneasy? My hands hesitated, scissors poised, as I wrestled with the demands of both worlds, feeling the weight of responsibility from each side pressing in.
